content.description:
Start low with your right hand in the cave and your left hand out of the cave on good crimps with an obvious left toe hook. Right foot smear. Slap your left hand up to a juggy slot, bring your feet in to the right hand start hold, and move your right hand up to another juggy slot below the left hand. Then pull for the top. I used a double toe hook, but it can easily be campused. The topout is a bit difficult.

 There is a beta video in the comments.
content.location: Take the trail from the parking lot as if you were going to the rock house, but instead of turning left to the rock house, turn right. The pond should be on your left, and the little stream should be on your right. The boulder is visible from the pond and is about 200 feet straight into the woods.

content.description: Start all the way down in the cave on the ground on a good jug and feet, bump to good crimp with your right hand, then make a big slap move up to a good sloper on the arete. From there, follow the arete all the way up the boulder, and top out using the good ledge off to the right.
content.protection: This is a very sketchy climb that will require at least 4 pads and 2 good spotters. Without good protection, you could get seriously hurt on a fall.
content.location: Climb on top of the Turdle Boulder, and shimmy your way down into the low cave sit start.

content.description: Start with both of your hands on a small jug on the bottom right side of the boulder, heel hook your right foot by your hands, and do a big reach up with your left hand to another small jug. Topping out is pretty simple from there.
content.location: This is to the right of turdle.

content.description: Start matched on a crystal edge above head height. Move right to a bad crimp, and then jump way right to a glory jug. Campus match, and then top out on jugs. You could start further towards the left, but the block behind you really detracts from the quality. A sit may work, but I couldn’t make it work
content.location: It is on the left side of the same boulder as The Reach.

content.description: Start with your right hand by two pockets and your left wherever. Work your way to the sloper and top out on the slab.
content.location: Walk in on the main trail, take a right at the pond, and it's the first boulder you see.

content.description: Start sitting with your left hand on a sloper you use as a starting toe hook for Turdle and your right hand on an edge. Pull on, and use some cool left hand edges to eventually bring your right hand up to the arete. Top out low directly above the start.
content.protection: A few pads, even though it’s low, you down want to break your butt on the blocks below it.
content.location: It is left and around the corner from Turdle.

content.description: This is a fun climb. The last part is walking your hands along the crack followed by a send to the next rock up.Alternative beta: send straight up instead of moving left, hence the name "Depends How You End It".

Start sitting on a pretty bad slopey crimp down and way left. Get creative with your toes, and pull off the ground. Move right through the juggy pockets to some crimps and slopers before you mantel onto the slab on the right.
This is a simple problem following a few solid crimp rails. From a sit start on the lowest crimp rail, keep bumping your hands, and top out.
content.location: Follow the trail behind Turtle Boulder about 200 feet into the woods. It should be on your right. The landing is on the trail.

content.description: Sit start on the left end of the rail left of the big pocket stance. Reach up to an OK triangular crimp with your left hand. Stand in the pocket, and then top out straight up. The crux is the topout.
content.location: It is on the right side of the Turdle Boulder.

content.description: Turdle is a good boulder with several problems.
